title: Russian book ban in Ukraine
text:
On December 30, 2016, President <a href="Petro%20Poroshenko">Petro Poroshenko</a> of <a href="Ukraine">Ukraine</a> signed into law a decree that restricts import of books into Ukraine from Russia.
According to the law, a person can bring at most 10 Russian books without a permit. Unauthorized distribution of books from Russia is under a penalty.
This is an element of the <a href="Russian%20military%20intervention%20in%20Ukraine%20%282014%E2%80%93present%29">ongoing military conflict between Ukraine and Russia</a>.
The law was considered in the <a href="Verkhovna%20Rada">Verkhovna Rada</a> (the Ukrainian parliament) since September 2016 and followed in spirit the 2015 ban of 38 books from Russia with the purpose of "safeguarding Ukrainian citizens against the use of information warfare and disinformation methods, against the spread of hate ideology, fascism, xenophobia and separatism". Among banned were books by <a href="Russian%20nationalist">Russian nationalist</a>s <a href="Alexander%20Dugin">Alexander Dugin</a>, <a href="Eduard%20Limonov">Eduard Limonov</a> and <a href="Sergei%20Glazyev">Sergei Glazyev</a>.
Russian books accounted for some 60% of the market, and the bookselling experts predicted a considerable disruption of the business, book shortages, as well as the growth of the book <a href="black%20market">black market</a>.
The <a href="State%20Committee%20for%20Television%20and%20Radio-broadcasting%20%28Ukraine%29">State Committee for Television and Radio-broadcasting</a>, whose duties include enforcing the information policy in Ukraine, is set in charge of book permits and is to issue bans on books deemed inappropriate which come "from territory of the aggressor state and from the <a href="War%20in%20Donbass">temporarily occupied territory of Ukraine</a>". Types of printed matter which require permits include books, brochures, children's books including <a href="coloring%20book">coloring book</a>s, as well as maps, <a href="atlas">atlas</a>es, <a href="globe">globe</a>s, etc. Each permit is to be entered into the special state register and is valid for at most 5 years. Bans are based on evaluations by a council of experts and may be contested.
For example, in August 2017, the Committee banned two novels of <a href="Boris%20Akunin">Boris Akunin</a> and memoirs of <a href="Vladimir%20Vysotsky">Vladimir Vysotsky</a>.
 In December 2018, it banned a number of children books from Russia about Russian epic <a href="bogatyr">bogatyr</a>s, as well as some memoirs and historical books.
In September 2018, <a href="Lviv">Lviv</a> Regional Council banned public use of Russian-language books, films and songs in the region until Russia's withdrawal from Ukraine.
